the interim project use agreement dated  with the solid waste agency of northern cook county pursuant to historical areas footnotes  1  cross reference administration ch 2  buildings ch 6  parks and recreation ch 14  planning and zoning generally ch 15  streets and sidewalks ch 18  trees shrubs and weeds ch 21  zoning app a  subdivision regulations app b article i  in general purpose the purpose of this chapter is to 1 safeguard the villages historic cultural architectural and community heritage as embodied in its landmarks  2 protect enhance and perpetuate the distinctive visual characteristics of the village of roselle  3 promote the educational cultural economic and general welfare of the village of roselle by providing for a mechanism whereby historic landmarks including landmarks reflecting local and regional culture which are located in the village of roselle may be identified as historically significant preserved in a suitable harmonious environment and studied and enjoyed now and hereafter  10879 definitions for the purposes of this chapter the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them alteration any act which changes the exterior architectural appearance of a structure or which changes the appearance of a site which has been designated as a landmark pursuant to this chapter board the village board of the village of roselle illinois certificate of appropriateness a certificate from the board authorizing plans for the alteration of or construction on a site or authorizing the alteration removal or demolition of a structure which has been designated as a landmark pursuant to this chapter demolition any act which destroys in part or in whole a structure exterior architectural appearance includes the architectural character a general composition and general arrangement of the exterior of a structure including the kind and texture of the building material and the type and character of all windows doors exterior walls roofing light fixtures signs and appurtenant elements visible from a public street or thoroughfare or from nearby property or improvements thereon landmark any site or structure which has special historical interest or which has special value as part of the heritage of the village of roselle or the nation state or region and which has been designated by the board as a landmark structure any building parking facility fence gate wall work of art or other object constituting a physical improvement to real property which has been designated by the board as a landmark or which is a part of any such physical improvement designated by the board as a landmark this definition of the word structure is different from the definition of the word in the villages building code and intended for purposes of this chapter only  10879   62287 article ii  board and administration jurisdiction and power of the board the board upon consultation with and recommendation of the roselle historical foundation shall have the authority to 1 designate sites and structures with the village as landmarks  2 prescribe conditions for their alteration demolition and removal  3 evaluate any application for zoning amendment variation or special use affecting any landmark pursuant to the purpose of this chapter as stated in section 851 such applications submitted to the zoning board of appeals shall be forwarded to the commission which in its discretion may present evidence at the public hearing on the proposed zoning amendment variation or special use either in support of or in opposition to or it may recommend modifications thereof  4 visually identify designated landmarks ie plaques markers etc  10879   62287 principles for decisionmaking in making its decisions the board shall be guided by the following principles 1 to be reasonable in judgment so as not to cause undue hardship to any property owner  2 to be careful in judgment so that the cost of the compliance is not so great as to constitute a taking of private property without just compensation  3 to be consistent in judgement with the purpose of this chapter and with the comprehensive plan of the village  10879   62287 landmark designation a landmark designation criteria landmarks are herein characterized as sites or structures which are 1 important to the development heritage or culture of the village  2 identified as the place of a significant historical event  3 identified with a person or persons who significantly contributed to the development of the village or of the region  4 possessed of distinguishing characteristics of an architectural style common in the village or general area  5 possessed of elements of architectural design details materials or craftsmanship which have historical significance  6 an established visual feature of the village  7 valuable for the study of a period style or method of construction  or 8 significant because of their unique utilitarian purpose b application for landmark designation 1 any person group of persons or association may request a landmark designation for any site or structure within the corporate limits of the village which may have historic significance as set forth in the criteria section in section 855a in this chapter the village clerk shall supply application forms upon request completed forms shall be returned to the village clerk who shall forward applications to the board 2 an application to designate property as a landmark shall contain the name and address of the owner of the property the location of the property including the street address the legal description of the property a physical description of the property including its external dimensions and other relevant data the reasons the property should be designated as a landmark according to the provisions of this chapter and the name and address of the person applying for landmark designation an application shall be signed by the applicant c action on application for landmark designation 1 within twenty 20 days after receipt of an application for landmark designation the board shall notify in writing the owner of the property of the proposed designation 2 upon receipt of the application the board shall schedule a public hearing to consider the application to be held within sixty 60 days at least twenty 20 days prior to the hearing the board shall give written notice to the owner and to the applicant of said hearing such notification shall set forth the date time and place of the hearing 3 the board shall arrange for public notice of the time date and place of the public hearing by publication at least once not more than thirty 30 and not less than fifteen 15 days before the hearing in a newspaper published in the village or in a newspaper with a general circulation in the village published in dupage or cook county the notice shall contain a brief description of and the location of the property proposed for landmark designation 4 at such hearing the applicant and the owner may be present with agents attorneys and experts of their choosing and they and any interested citizen may present their respective position in the matter at such hearing the board shall hear testimony and argument and admit evidence relating to the designation of the property as a landmark of the village the hearing may be continued on the direction of the board but shall be concluded within sixty 60 days after it is opened 5 within fortyfive 45 days after the close of the public hearing the board shall decide whether or not to designate the property being considered as a landmark of the village the decision of the board shall be written and mailed to the property owner and to the applicant within ten 10 days after it is made d voting on landmark designation a decision to designate property as a landmark of the village shall be made by a majority of the members of the board e appeal of designation decision if the property owner or the applicant wishes to appeal the boards decision to the board he may do so such appeal shall be made by requesting in writing a review of the decision of the board by the board such request shall be made to the village clerk within fifteen 15 days after notification of the boards decision procedures before the board shall be as provided by village ordinance and by law the board shall consider and vote on the appeal within sixty 60 days after it is received by the village clerk further appeal to the courts shall be as provided by law  10879   62287 discharge from alteration visible from a public way or from nearby property in respect to a landmark without there having been issued a certificate of appropriateness by the commission relating to such construction demolition movement or alteration b application for certificate of appropriateness 1 an application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be filed with the village clerk who shall promptly submit it to the board the village clerk shall have available and dispense upon request forms for such an application to any owner or developer of a designated landmark 2 the application for a certificate of appropriateness shall contain the name and address of the applicant and of the owner of the landmark if different from the applicant the name and address of the applicants attorney if any the name and address of the architect if any for the applicant the street address of the property the legal description of the site or parcel of property on which the structure is located a detailed description of the site or structure a complete description of the proposed construction demolition movement or alteration and drawings or sketches that are available and helpful in showing what is proposed the description of what is to be done must be such as to enable an unsophisticated layman to accurately determine what the final appearance and use will be the application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be signed by the applicant 3 a copy of the application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be forwarded to the building inspector no application for a building permit affecting the construction alteration demolition or movement of a landmark shall be approved by the building inspector unless a copy of the certificate of appropriateness has been issued for the same work c processing of application for certificate of appropriateness 1 if the board receives an application for a certificate of appropriateness which on its face shows that failure to promptly grant the certificate of appropriateness will cause a substantial and imminent threat to health safety life or property then said chairman shall convene an emergency meeting of the board as soon as possible but within seven 7 days after such receipt by the chairman the board shall inform the applicant of the date time and place of the meeting at such a meeting the applicant andor his representatives may present evidence testimony and argument in support of the contention that failure to issue the certificate of appropriateness will cause a substantial and imminent threat to health safety life or property if the board by a threefourths 34 majority vote of the members present at such meeting decides that failure to promptly grant a certificate of appropriateness will because a substantial and imminent threat to health safety life or property the commission shall waive the normal review procedures prescribed in section 857c2 57c8 of this chapter and will promptly issue the certificate of appropriateness if the board decides that failure to promptly grant a certificate of appropriateness will not cause substantial or imminent threat to health safety life or property the application for the certificate of appropriateness will be reviewed according to the procedures prescribed in section 857c2 57c8 of this chapter 2 upon receipt of an application for a certificate of appropriateness which does not show that failure to act promptly will cause an imminent and substantial threat to health safety life or property the board shall schedule a public hearing to consider the application to be held within sixty 60 days after receipt of the application within ten 10 days after the receipt of the application the board shall arrange for written notice to the applicant of the date time and place of the hearing when the application will be considered 3 the board shall arrange for public notice of the time date and place of the public hearing by publication at least once not more than thirty 30 days nor less than fifteen 15 days before the public hearing in a newspaper with a general circulation in the village published in dupage or cook county the notice shall contain a brief description of the property its location and the proposed construction demolition alteration or movement for which a certificate of appropriateness is sought 4 at the hearing the applicant his representative and any interested citizen may present their position in the matter the board shall hear testimony and argument and admit evidence relating to the application for the certificate of appropriateness the hearing may be continued upon direction of the board but shall be concluded within sixty 60 days after it is opened 5 during the hearing on the application for the certificate of appropriateness the board members shall make known their objections if any to the applicant regarding the application consideration may be given to minimizing or removing the adverse effect if any which the proposed alteration construction movement or demolition would have on the landmark consideration may be given to alternative means if there are such of accomplishing the purpose of the applicant consideration may be given to the use proposed by the applicant for the landmark the application for the certificate of appropriateness may be amended by the applicant upon a majority of the board members present to do so 6 within fortyfive 45 days after the close of the hearing the board shall either approve or disapprove the application if by a majority vote of the members of the board the application for certificate of appropriateness is approved the board shall promptly issue the certificate under his or her signature within ten 10 days after the decision is made copies of the certificate shall be forwarded to the owner applicant and to the building inspector 7 if the application for the certificate of appropriateness is not approved by a majority vote of the members of the board the board shall notify the applicant and the building inspector in writing of the disapproval and of the reasons for the disapproval 8 the factors to be considered and the standards for issuance or denial of the certificate of appropriateness shall be those set forth in section 857f of this chapter d criteria for issuance of certificates of appropriateness 1 if the board finds that the alteration construction movement or demolition proposed in the application for a certificate of appropriateness will not adversely affect any significant historical architectural or aesthetic feature of the property and is consistent with the spirit and purpose of this chapter the commission shall issue a certificate of appropriateness 2 in making a determination whether or not to issue a certificate of appropriateness the board may consider among other things the following a the effect upon all exterior architectural features including signs fences porches outbuildings landscaping paving and other appurtenances  b the violation of the general design and arrangement  c the modification to texture materials patterns and colors  and d the change in height shape scale and proportion 3 in making a determination whether or not to issue a certificate of appropriateness the board shall be governed by the following standards a every reasonable effort should be made to provide a use for a building which will require minimum alteration to the building and its environment b rehabilitation work should not destroy the distinguishing quality or character of the property the removal or alteration of any historical or architectural features should be held to the minimum the proposed work should preserve highlight or enhance the historic or architectural character of the building c deteriorated features should be repaired rather than replaced whenever possible in the event that replacement is necessary the new material should match the material being replaced in composition design texture and other visual qualities d some changes to buildings and environments which have taken place in the course of time are evidence of the history of the building these changes may have developed significance in their own right and this significance should be recognized and respected e all buildings should be recognized as products of their own time alterations to create an appearance inconsistent with the actual character of the building should be discouraged f whenever possible additions or alterations to a building should be done in such a manner that if they were removed in the future the essential form and integrity of the original would be unimpaired g contemporary design for additions to existing buildings should not be discouraged if such design is compatible with the size scale color material and character of the building and its immediate environment e procedures following denial of application for certificate of appropriateness 1 if after the public hearing an application for a certificate of appropriateness is disapproved by the board said application will be denied for a period of not more than nine 9 months during this period the board and the owner or applicant or their representative shall bargain in respect to the objections raised by the board to the action proposed in the application for the certificate of appropriateness at least two 2 weeks prior to a meeting for such bargaining the board shall give written notice to the applicant or his representatives such meetings must be scheduled at reasonable times and not more frequently than is necessary for reasonable consideration of the boards objections and fair exploration of alternatives at such meetings there may be consultation with private civic groups interested private citizens and public boards or agencies in an effort to find a means of preserving the landmark consideration may be given to alternative use or sale of property consideration may be given to anything that would tend to preserve the site or structure as a landmark 2 if after the period of denial no agreement has been reached between the board and the applicant and if the applicant has reasonably explored alternatives to the proposed activity in accordance with the aforementioned procedures then the board shall issue the certificate of appropriateness in accordance with section 857c6 of this chapter 3 in granting the certificate of appropriateness the board may prescribe any conditions it deems necessary consistent with the granting of the certificate of appropriateness f appeal of decision if the owner or applicant wishes to appeal the decision of the board to the village board he may do so such appeal shall be made by requesting in writing a review of the boards decision by the board such request shall be made to the village clerk by the owner or applicant within fifteen 15 days after being notified of the boards decision procedures before the board shall be as provided by village ordinances and by law the board shall consider and vote on the appeal within sixty 60 days after it is received by the village clerk further appeal to the courts shall be provided by law  10879   62287 alternate landmark designation a the board may enter into an agreement with a property owner or other party in control of a parcel of property whether the property is improved or unimproved for the purpose of providing for the designation of such property as an official landmark in the village of roselle b such agreement shall provide for the placing of a plaque upon such property in a manner acceptable to the board and such property owner or other party in control of such property the nature of the plaque the positioning of the plaque upon the property and the manner in which it is affixed to the property may be included in such agreement c such agreement shall provide that the board or the property owner or other party in control of the property with whom the agreement is made may at any time upon two 2 weeks notice to the other party remove the plaque on such property giving or not giving a reason therefor if substantial demolition of a designated landmark property is anticipated notice by the property owner or other party in control to the board for the removal of the plaque from such property shall be given at least thirty 30 days prior to such removal in such case notice shall include notification of the intention of such substantial demolition upon the removal of such plaque such property shall no longer be an historical landmark in the village of roselle in the event the owner or other party in control of the property at the time the agreement is made is not the same person or entity as the owner or other party in control of the property at the time such notice is sought to be given such notice may be given by or given to and such removal may be made by the owner or the other party in control of the property as the case may be at the time such notice is sought to be given d property designated as landmark property as of  pursuant to section 855 of this be discharged from landmark status in accordance with the following procedure written notice shall be given by the board to the owner or other party in control of such property within sixty 60 days after adoption of this section 858 such notice shall briefly explain the far less restrictive and nonbinding nature of landmark designation under this section 858 such notice shall advise the owner or other party in control that within sixty 60 days after the receipt of such notice the owner or other party in control may request in writing to the board that such property be discharged from landmark status under this section 858 and that upon receipt of such request by the board such property shall be designated from landmark status such notice by the board shall also advise that such request by the owner or other party in control may include a request for landmark status under this section 858 and that if made such request will be granted  21384   62287 enforcement  penalties for violation a every owner whether the owner is an and for which a certificate of appropriateness has not been issued such owner or developer upon conviction shall be fined not less than twenty dollars $2000 nor more than two hundred dollars $20000 for each violation and each offense every day an offense exists shall constitute a separate violation b in addition to the aforedescribed penalty the village may bring an appropriate suit to enjoin any act undertaken by an owner or developer in violation of this chapter and to require restoration of any landmark to its condition prior to such unauthorized act  10879   21384 relationship to other division 1  generally definitions as used in this division canteen truck vendor shall mean any person engaged in the retail delivery or sale or products of food and drink by a motorized vehicle used to reach the sites from which delivery or sale is authorized by section 9151e caterer shall mean any person engaged in the preparation andor serving of food at a location other than the principal place of business employee shall mean any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils or who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served food store shall mean grocery store butcher shop delicatessen store confectionery store bakery store butter and egg store milk store fruit and vegetable store fish store drugstore ice cream store or any combination of the foregoing or any place where food or drink is prepared handled stored offered for sale or sold at wholesale or retail itinerant restaurant shall mean one operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair carnival circus public exhibition or other similar gatherings itinerant vendor shall mean any person engaged in the house to house delivery or sale of any products of food and drink mobile vendor shall mean any person engaged in the delivery or sale of products of food and drink but only at a designated or specific site owned or leased by the village openair market shall mean any establishment engaged only in the handling and storage of fruits and vegetables offered for sale or sold at wholesale or retail such establishment not being entirely enclosed restaurant shall mean restaurant coffee shop cafeteria short order cafe luncheonette tavern sandwich stand soda fountain and all other eating and drinking establishments as well as kitchens or other places in which food or drink is prepared for sale elsewhere utensils shall mean any kitchenware tableware glassware cutlery utensils or containers or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during storage preparation or serving art ii  1 22458   2783   31691   82393 compliance required from and after twelve 12 months of the date of its first inspection no existing restaurant or food store shall continue to operate within the village unless it conforms with the grade a or grade b requirements of this division and no existing openair market or itinerant vendor shall operate without conforming to the approved openair market or itinerant vendor requirements of this division no restaurant or food store shall open for business unless it conforms to the grade a requirements of this division and no openair market or itinerant vendor shall begin operating without conforming to the requirements of this division itinerant restaurants must comply with the itinerant restaurant requirements of this division before they will be permitted to operate art ii  8 22458 license required it shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the village without having first secured a license therefor applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this thereto and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or handled the annual license fee for the food dealers shall be as prescribed by section 916  permits required  posting it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant itinerant restaurant food store openair market or to operate as an itinerant vendor of food in the village who does not possess an unrevoked permit from the health officer such permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place only persons who comply with the requirements of this division shall be entitled to receive and retain such a permit art ii  2 22458 suspension revocation of permit a permit required by this division may be temporarily suspended by the health officer upon the violation by the holder of any of the terms of this division or revoked after an opportunity for a hearing by the health officer upon serious or repeated violation art ii  2 22458 display of grade placard the health officer shall post in a conspicuous place in every restaurant and food store a decalcomania or placard stating the grade of the establishment relocating removing obliterating or concealing in any way said decalcomania or placard or causing or inducing its relocation removal obliteration or concealment shall be deemed a violation of this operator of any restaurant or food store shall notify the health officer within twentyfour 24 hours of any damage to or deterioration of the decalcomania or placard which seriously impairs its legibility art ii  3 22458 examination condemnation of unwholesome adulterated food and drink samples of food and drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the health officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration the health officer may condemn and forbid the sale of or cause to be removed or destroyed any food or drink which is unwholesome or adulterated art ii  4 22458 inspections at least once every six 6 months the health officer shall inspect every restaurant and food store located within the village in case the health officer discovers the violation of any item of sanitation required for the grade then held he shall make a second inspection after the lapse of such time as he deems necessary for the defect to be remedied and the second inspection shall be used in determining compliance with the grade requirements of this article any violation of the same item of this article on such second inspection shall call for immediate degrading or suspension of the permit art ii  5 22458 inspection reports one copy of the inspection report shall be posted by the health officer upon an inside wall of the restaurant or food store and said inspection report shall not be defaced or removed by any person except the health officer another copy of the inspection report shall be filed with the records of the health department art ii  5 22458 cooperation with health officer the person operating the restaurant or food store shall upon request of the health officer permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall permit copying any or all records of food purchased art ii  5 22458 requirements for grade a establishments all grade a restaurants and food stores shall comply with all of the following items of sanitation item 1 floors  the floors of all rooms in which food or drink is stored prepared or served or in which utensils are washed shall be of such construction as to be easily cleaned shall be smooth and shall be kept clean and in good repair item 2 walls and ceilings  walls and ceilings of all rooms shall be kept clean and in good repair all walls and ceilings of rooms in which food or drink is stored or prepared shall be finished in light color the walls of all rooms in which food or drink is prepared or utensils are washed shall have a smooth washable surface up to the level reached by splash or spray item 3 doors and windows  when flies are prevalent all openings into the outer air shall be effectively screened and doors shall be selfclosing unless other effective means are provided to prevent the entrance of flies item 4 lighting  all rooms in which food or drink is stored or prepared or in which utensils are washed shall be well lighted item 5 ventilation  all rooms in which food or drink is stored prepared or served or in which utensils are washed shall be well ventilated item 6 toilet facilities  every restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees conforming with the ordinances of the village in restaurants hereafter constructed toilet rooms shall not open directly into any room in which food drink or utensils are handled or stored the doors of all toilet rooms shall be selfclosing toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition in good repair and well lighted and ventilated handwashing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees in case privies or earth closets are permitted and used they shall be separate from the restaurant building and shall be of a sanitary type constructed and operated in conformity with the standards of the state board of health item 7 water supply  running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in which food is prepared or utensils are washed and the water supply shall be adequate and of a safe sanitary quality item 8 lavatory facilities  adequate and convenient handwashing facilities shall be provided including hot and cold running water soap and approved sanitary towels the use of a common towel is prohibited no employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without first washing his hands item 9 construction of utensils and equipment  all multiuse utensils and all show and display cases or windows counters shelves tables refrigerating equipment sinks and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of a restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used  provided that solder containing lead may be used for jointing item 10 cleaning and bactericidal treatment of utensils and equipment  all equipment including display cases or windows counters shelves tables refrigerators stoves hoods and sinks shall be kept clean and free from dust dirt insects and other contaminating material all cloths used by waiters chefs and other employees shall be clean singleservice containers shall be used only once all multiuse eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each usage all multiuse utensils used in the preparation or serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process immediately following the days operation drying cloths if used shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose no article polish or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous material shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils item 11 storage and handling of utensils and equipment  after bactericidal treatment utensils shall be stored in a clean dry place protected from flies dust and other contamination and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable singleservice utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers shall be stored therein in a clean dry place until used and shall be handled in a sanitary manner item 12 disposal of wastes  all wastes shall be properly disposed of and all garbage and trash shall be kept in suitable receptacles in such manner as not to become a nuisance item 13 refrigeration  all readily perishable food or drink shall be kept at or below fifty 50 degrees fahrenheit except when being prepared or served waste water from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of item 14 wholesomeness of food and drink  all food and drink shall be clean wholesome free from spoilage and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption all milk fluid milk products ice cream and other frozen desserts served shall be from approved sources milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual original containers in which they were received from the distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device  provided that this requirement shall not apply to cream which may be served from the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service all oysters clams and mussels shall be from approved sources and if shucked shall be kept until used in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant item 15 storage display serving of food and drink  all food and drink shall be so stored displayed and served as to be protected from dust flies vermin depredation and pollution by rodents unnecessary handling droplet infection overhead leakage and other contamination no animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored all means necessary for the elimination of flies roaches and rodents shall be used item 16 cleanliness of employees  all employees shall wear clean outer garments and shall keep their hands clean at all times while engaged in handling food drink utensils or equipment employees shall not expectorate or use tobacco in any form in a room in which food is prepared item 17 miscellaneous  the premises of all restaurants shall be kept clean and free from litter or rubbish none of the operations connected with a restaurant shall be conducted in any room used as living or sleeping quarters adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees clothing and shall be kept clean soiled linens coats and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for this purpose art ii  6 22458 requirements for grade b establishments grade b restaurants and food stores are those which fail to comply with items 1 2 4 5 or 17 but which conform with all other items of sanitation required for grade a restaurants or food stores art ii  6 22458 what constitutes grade c establishments grade c restaurants and food stores are those which fail to comply with either the grade a or b requirements art ii  6 22458 itinerant restaurants a itinerant restaurants shall be constructed and operated in an approved manner the health officer shall approve an itinerant restaurant only if it complies with the following sanitation requirements 1 it shall be located in clean surroundings and kept in clean and sanitary condition 2 it shall be so constructed and arranged that food drink utensils and equipment will not be unduly exposed to insects or to dust or other contamination 3 only food and drink which is clean wholesome and free from adulteration shall be sold or served 4 an adequate supply of water of safe sanitary quality shall be easily available and used for drinking and for cleaning utensils and equipment 5 if multiuse utensils are used in the serving of food or drink they shall be thoroughly washed with hot water and a satisfactory detergent and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each use and so handled and kept as to be protected from contamination adequate provisions shall be made for refrigeration of perishable food and drink 6 ice used in or with food or drink shall be from a source approved by the health officer and so handled as to avoid contamination 7 garbage and refuse shall be kept in tightly covered watertight containers until removed and shall be disposed of in a place and manner approved by the health officer 8 dishwater and other liquid wastes shall be disposed of so as not to create a nuisance 9 no person suffering from any disease transmissible by contact or or drink or who is the carrier of the germs of such a disease shall be employed in any capacity 10 adequate and satisfactory toilet and handwashing facilities shall be readily accessible to employees 11 no person engaged in the handling or serving of food and drink shall return to his work after using the toilet without first thoroughly washing his hands b upon failure of any person maintaining or oparating an itinerant restaurant after warning to comply with any of these requirements it shall be the duty of the health officer summarily to forbid the further sale or serving of food or drink therein any person continuing to serve or sell food or drink in such a restaurant after being so forbidden shall be subject to the penalties provided for violation of this art ii  7 22458 itinerant vendors mobile vendors and canteen truck vendors a itinerant vendors mobile vendors and canteen truck vendors of food shall operate in an approved manner the health officer shall approve an itinerant vendor mobile vendor or a canteen truck vendor only if such a vendor complies with the following sanitation requirements 1 vehicles used in the delivery of food and drink shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and the vehicle shall be so constructed and arranged that food drink utensils and equipment will not be exposed to insects rodents dust or other contamination 2 only food and drink which is clean wholesome and free from adulteration shall be sold or delivered 3 adequate provisions shall be made for refrigeration of perishable food and drink 4 no person suffering from any disease transmissible by contact or drink or who is the carrier of the germs of such a disease shall be employed in any capacity b the health officer shall summarily forbid the further sale or delivery of food or drink by any vendor operating as an itinerant vendor mobile vendor or a canteen truck vendor after warning to comply with any of these requirements any vendor continuing to sell or deliver food or drink after being so forbidden shall be subject to the penalties provided for the violation of this c it shall be unlawful for any mobile vendor to operate on property owned or leased by the village without first obtaining a written lease or sublease from the village d a mobile vendor shall be construed to be a nonmoving vehicle as provided for in section 1821 of of the ordinances e a canteen truck vendor shall be licensed village to sell dispense and distribute by moving vehicle on private property where prior permission has been granted by the property owner canteen trucks shall not deliver or sell food or drink within any public highway or rightofway in the village art ii  7 22458   2783   82393 openair markets a openair markets shall be operated in an approved manner the health officer shall approve an openair market only if it complies with the following sanitation requirements 1 it shall be located in an area that is clean well drained and the area shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition 2 all fruits and vegetables which are not encased customers and from contamination by dust and flies 3 all equipment and utensils used in the storing display preparation and handling of fruits and vegetables must be kept clean 4 an adequate supply of suffering from any disease transmissible by contact or or drink or who is the carrier of the germs of such a disease shall be employed in any capacity 7 adequate and satisfactory toilet and handwashing facilities shall be readily accessible to employees 8 no person engaged in the handling of fruits and vegetables shall return to his work after using the toilet without first thoroughly washing his hands b upon failure of any person maintaining or operating an openair market after warning to comply with any of these requirements it shall be the duty of the health officer summarily to forbid the sale of fruits and vegetables therein any person continuing to sell fruits or vegetables in such an openair market after being so forbidden shall be subject to the penalties provided for again complying with the higher grade requirements and in case the findings indicate compliance shall award the higher grade or reinstate the permit art ii  9 22458 diseased employees prohibited no merchandise or services and operating under the auspices of a notforprofit corporation  42588 certain items prohibited itinerant merchants participating in a licensed flea market shall be prohibited be qualified to obtain a flea market permit c flea markets shall be permitted in all zoning districts d an application for a flea market permit shall be made upon a form provided by the village clerk and shall contain all of the following information 1 the name and business address and telephone number of the notforprofit corporation or charitable institution and the name address and telephone beverages will occur e the application shall be filed not less than thirty 30 days prior to the scheduled date of the flea market failure to file on time shall constitute a denial of the permit f section the terms specified in this section have the meanings ascribed to them in this paragraph a service station  any place of business where class i ii or iii liquids are sold or offered for sale at retail and dispensed into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles b selfservice station  that portion of property of a service station where flammable and combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and subsequently dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles by persons other than the service station attendant c approved selfservice dispensing device  any device for the dispensing of class i ii or iii liquids into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles as approved by the state fire marshal pursuant to the rules and regulations relating to the storage transportation sale and use of gasoline and volatile oils but shall not include dispensing devices which are coin or card operated d owner  any individuals or legal entity holding title lease village clerk e attendant  the owner or any person who is paid wages by an owner of a service station to dispense motor fuel at such service station 3 the following rules shall be adhered to at all selfservice stations and violation of any said rules shall constitute good and just cause for suspension or revocation of a selfservice station permit by the state fire marshal a the installation or use of unattended selfservice dispensing devices for motor fuel of any kind is hereby prohibited b no dwelling unit or sleeping facilities of any kind for the owner attendant or any person shall be permitted at a selfservice station c dispensing of class i ii or iii liquids at locations not open to the public does not require an attendant or supervisor such locations may be used by commercial industrial governmental or manufacturing establishments for fueling vehicles used in connection with their businesses however this shall not include private fraternal clubs or associations d special dispensing devices for motor fuel are not to be installed or used without prior written approval of the state fire marshal e approved selfservice dispensing devices are permitted at service stations available and open to the public provided that all dispensing of class i ii or iii liquids by a person other than the service station attendant is under the supervision and control of a qualified attendant and the dispensing nozzle is a listed automatic closing type without a hold open latch and must be approved by the state fire marshal f it shall be the responsibility of the attendant to 1 dispense class i ii or iii liquids into approved portable containers  2 control sources of ignition  and 3 immediately handle accidental spills and fire extinguishers if needed the attendant on duty shall be mentally and physically capable of performing the functions and assuming the responsibility prescribed in this section g one type abc fire extinguisher with a capacity of ten 10 pounds shall be provided for each pump island containing four 4 or less dispensing pumps  on pump islands containing more than four 4 dispensing pumps an additional extinguisher shall be provided for each four 4 additional dispensing pumps or fraction thereof such extinguishers shall be plainly marked shall be protected from the weather and shall be maintained in operable condition and available at all times when the selfservice station is open to the public such extinguishers shall be located at points approved by the state fire marshal away from the dispensing area but close enough to the dispensing area to be readily available all employees of the selfservice station shall be thoroughly instructed as to the locations and proper use of such extinguishers and shall upon request demonstrate their ability in such use to the approval of representatives of the state fire marshal h signs giving instructions for the operation of gasoline dispensing equipment shall be conspicuously posted at each purpose a it is the purpose of this article to protect the health and welfare of the citizens of the village of roselle to ensure clear direction to the police department in the regulation of commercial and noncommercial solicitation  and to protect the first amendment rights of solicitors canvassers and peddlers operating within the village of roselle it is further declared to be the policy of the corporate authorities of the village of roselle that the occupants of residences commercial establishments or industrial buildings premises located within in the village have the right to determine whether any solicitor canvasser or peddler shall be invited to their respective premises and those persons who violate the provisions of this article constitute a public and private nuisance and a detriment to the health safety and welfare of the residents of the village of roselle b the operation of any solicitor canvasser or peddler in conformance with the terms of this article shall not be interpreted to be an endorsement of any solicitor canvasser or peddler by the village of roselle its elected officials or employees  102802 definitions for purposes of this article the following words as used herein shall be construed to have the following meaning premises a premise shall mean and include every separate unit occupied for any purpose by one or more persons contained within any type of building or structure solicitsolicitation solicitsolicitation shall mean and include any one or more of the following activities any attempt or activity in furtherance of selling acquiring or otherwise obtaining orders or contracts for the purchase of goods wares merchandise food products or any other property of any kind character or description including but not limited to real estate and personal property of any kind or type or services of any kind character or description whatsoever for any kind of consideration whatsoever  and any activity which is carried on for the benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association organization corporation or project or which seeks the contributions of alms food clothing money subscriptions property or donations with or without an exchange of consideration  102802 premises occupant notice prohibiting solicitation a any citizen of the village of roselle desiring to prohibit solicitors canvassers or peddlers from their premises shall post a sign indicating that solicitors canvassers or peddlers are prohibited from entering onto the premises  and attach the sign to the principal structure located on the premises near or at the main entrance to said structure  and the text of such sign shall be at least onethird inch in height and state no solicitors invited b if the principal structure on any premises is divided into multiple premises or dwelling units each occupant of a premise to avail themselves of this article may post a sign in conformance with the requirements of subsection a of this section c signs posted as provided herein shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor or canvasser that they are not permitted at or on the premises  102802 duty of solicitors a it shall be the duty of every solicitor canvasser or peddler going upon any property within in the village of roselle to examine the area near or on the main entrance to said building or structure to determine whether it is posted with a notice consistent with this article if a sign is posted consistent with the terms of this article the solicitors shall immediately and peacefully depart from the property b not withstanding the prohibitions set forth in this article any solicitor canvasser or peddler who has gained entry to any premises within the village whether invited or not shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by any occupant thereof such requests shall be phrased so as to lead a reasonable person to understand that they are no longer welcome on the premises if a solicitor canvasser or peddler fails to comply with the requirements of this paragraph said failure shall constitute a separate distinct and additional act of uninvited solicitation as prohibited by this article  102802 uninvited solicitation prohibited it shall be a violation of this article for any solicitor canvasser or peddler to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or at or near any door or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant in such premises for the purposes of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in any solicitation as defined herein in contravention or defiance of any notice exhibited at the premises in accordance with the provisions of this article  102802 time limit on soliciting a it shall be unlawful and constitute a trespass for any solicitor canvasser or peddler to go upon any premises and ring any door bell at upon or near any door of any premises located thereon or rap or knock upon solicitation as defined herein prior to  am or after  pm on any weekday or prior to  am or after  pm on any weekend day b each premises visited in violation of this section shall constitute a separate and distinct violation of this article and shall be punishable by separate fine solicitation on roadways only persons soliciting or canvassing for any notforprofit company or organization any notice by the parent or guardian said notice may be made by any available means including telephone and certified or registered mailing return receipt requested prior to performing an abortion on a minor without the parents consent the treating physician shall execute an affidavit properly attested that the notice provisions of this section have been satisfied  10879 abortions during first service to the applicant or licensee setting forth the particular reasons for the proposed action an applicant or licensee aggrieved by an action of the village president shall be given the opportunity for a hearing before the president and board of trustees if a hearing is requested the applicant or licensee shall be advised five 5 working days in advance of the hearing of the time date and location of the hearing on the basis of the hearing the president and board of trustees shall make the final decision to issue suspend deny or revoke the license a copy of the determination shall business shall be defined as any business that involves the retail sale or distribution of material goods or chattels  31691 license required it shall be unlawful for any person firm or corporation to conduct maintain operate carryon or manage a general retail business without first having obtained a license as herein provided  31691 applications all applications for licenses required by this article shall be made to the village clerk in writing and shall state thereon the location of the applicable business for which the license is intended  31691 license fee the annual fee for any license required by this article shall be as prescribed in section 916  31691 secs 96199628  reserved article x  telecommunications division 1  generally purpose the purpose and intent of this article is to 1 establish a local policy concerning telecommunications providers and services  2 establish clear local guidelines standards and time frames for the exercise of local authority with respect to the regulation of telecommunications providers and services  3 promote competition in telecommunications  4 minimize unnecessary local regulation of telecommunications providers and services  5 encourage the provision of advanced and competitive telecommunications services on the widest possible basis to the businesses institutions and residents of the village  6 permit and manage reasonable access to the public ways of the village for telecommunications purposes on a competitively neutral basis  7 conserve the limited physical capacity of the public ways held in public trust by the village  8 assure that the villages current and ongoing costs of granting and regulating private access to and use of the public ways are fully paid by the persons seeking such access and causing such costs  9 secure fair and reasonable compensation to the village and the residents of the village for permitting private use of the public ways  10 assure that all telecommunications carriers providing facilities or services within the village comply with the ordinances rules and regulations of the village  11 assure that the village can continue to fairly and responsibly protect the public health safety and welfare  12 enable the village to discharge its public trust consistent with rapidly evolving federal and state regulatory policies industry competition and technological development  definitions for the purpose of this article and the interpretation and enforcement thereof the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings unless the context of the sentence in which annual gross revenue reserved cable act shall mean the cable communications policy act of 198 47 usc  532 et seq as now and hereafter amended cable operator means a telecommunications carrier cable act corporate authorities means the president and board of trustees of the village excess capacity means the volume or capacity in any existing or future duct conduit manhole handhole or other utility facility within the public way that is or will be available for use for additional telecommunications facilities fcc or federal communications commission means the federal administrative to the extent of the villages right title interest or authority to grant a license or franchise to occupy and use such streets and easements for telecommunications facilities state means the state of illinois surplus space means that portion of the usable space on a utility pole which has the necessary clearance from other pole users as required by the orders and regulations of the illinois commerce commission to allow its use by a telecommunications carrier for a pole attachment telecommunications carrier means and includes every person that directly or indirectly owns controls operates currently occupies the same public way shall relocate its facilities underground within a reasonable period of time which shall not be later than the end of the grant term absent extraordinary circumstances or undue hardship as determined by the village engineer such relocation shall be made concurrently to minimize the disruption of the public ways 5 whenever new telecommunications facilities will exhaust the capacity of a public street or utility easement to reasonably accommodate future telecommunications carriers or facilities the grantee shall provide additional ducts customer service and privacy protection law a adoption the regulations of 220 ilcs 570501 are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the cable or video providers offering services within the villages corporate boundaries b amendments any amendment to the cable and video customer protection law that becomes effective after the effective date of this chapter shall be incorporated into this chapter by reference and shall be applicable to cable or video providers offering services within the municipalitys boundaries however any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this chapter by reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village  121707 enforcement the village does hereby pursuant to law declares its intent to enforce the customer service and privacy protection standards of the cable and video protection law with respect to complaints received from residents within the village except where village staff determines that the village does not have the resources or expertise necessary to enforce said customer service and privacy protections in which case staff shall refer the complainant to the attorney general office  121707 penalties the village pursuant to 220 ilcs 570501r1 does hereby provide for a schedule of penalties for any material breach of the cable and video protection law by cable or video providers in addition to the penalties provided in the law the monetary penalties shall apply on a competitively neutral basis and shall not exceed $75000 for each day of the material breach and shall not exceed $2500000 for each occurrence of a material breach per customer a material breach means any substantial failure of a cable or video provider to comply with service quality and other standards specified in any provision of the law b the village shall give the cable or video provider written notice of any alleged material breaches of the law and allow such provider at least thirty 30 days from the receipt of the notice to remedy the specified material breach c a material breach for the purposes of assessing penalties shall be deemed to occur for each day that a material breach has not been remedied by the cable or video service provider after the notice in b  121707 customer credits the village hereby adopts the schedule of customer credits for violations those credits shall be as provided for in the provisions of 220 ilcs 570501s and applied on the statement issued to the customer for the next billing cycle following the violation or following the discovery of the violation the cable or video provider is responsible for providing the credits and the customer is under no obligation to request the credit  121707 be sent by mail postage prepaid to the address listed on the holders application notice sent pursuant to 220 ilcs 521401b6 to the village e payment date the payment of the service provider fee shall be due on a quarterly basis fortyfive 45 days after the close of the calendar quarter if mailed the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee f exemption the fee hereby imposed does not apply to existing cable service or video service providers that have an existing franchise agreement with the village in which a fee is paid g credit for other payments an incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 ilcs 521301c with credit for prepaid franchise fees under that agreement may deduct the amount of such credit from the fees that operator owes under section 9785b  applicable principles all determinations and calculations under this chapter shall be made pursuant to generally accepted accounting principles  no impact on other taxes due from holder nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to exempt a holder from any tax that is or may later be imposed by the village including any tax that is or may later be required to be paid by or holder with respect to cable service or video service a stateissued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the villages simplified municipal telecommunications tax or any other tax as it applies to any telephone service provided by past due shall be governed by ordinances adopted by this municipality pursuant to the local government taxpayers bill of rights act 50 ilcs 451 et seq  secs 97909899  reserved article xiii  special event permits legislative findings and statement of policy a the village board finds that from time to time persons and entities host or sponsor events that require the village to provide special services beyond the services the village customarily provides on an equal basis to its citizens  and b the village board further finds that providing special services as defined below effects the health safety and general welfare of the village and it requires the village to reallocate its personnel equipment and property imposes additional costs on the village exposes the village to additional liability interferes with the villages normal operations and can interfere with the safe use of the villages public ways and the villages property  and c the village board further finds that persons or entities who fail to provide the village with adequate notice of a need for special services deprive the village of the ability to plan for the allocation of its resources and therefore further jeopardize and undermine the villages ability to provide for the public health safety and welfare  and d the village board further finds that special services as further defined herein increase the villages operational costs  and e the village board further finds that granting or denying a special event permit shall not be based on the content of any expression protected by the first amendment that may occur during a special event  statement of policy it is therefore the policy of the village that any person or entity which hosts or sponsors an event that requires the village to provide special services shall pay the villages costs of providing such special services it is also the policy of the village that the allocation of the villages resources and the setting of fees and charges for their use for special events shall be done pursuant to content neutral standards and procedures  definitions and exclusions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning official visit or appearance means a visit or appearance of an elected official that is paid for with public funds and that is open to the general public special event means any organized gathering of people on public or private property for any purpose for a limited period of time which is sponsored by a forprofit or nonprofit individual group organization or entity at which any two 2 or more of the following shall apply 1 the requirement for the village to provide special services is contemplated or is deemed necessary by village personnel to maintain public health safety and welfare  2 the event requires the use of village property  3 the event is expected to have a visual noise or other environmental impact upon the immediate vicinity or surrounding area of the event 4 the event involves the distribution or selling of alcoholic beverages exclusions for purposes of this article the following shall not be considered special events 1 an official visit or appearance of the following elected officials a president or vice president of the united states b governor of the state of illinois c incumbent united states senator of the state of illinois d incumbent members of the united states congress in the districts in which the village of roselle is located e other state or federal officials  or dignitaries from foreign countries as determined by the village board 2 an activity or event sponsored by or held in conjunction with a governmental entity that is conducted on property where such events are normally held including but not limited to graduation ceremonies and athletic events 3 an activity or event that occurs outside the corporate limits of the village which village personnel services andor resources are provided pursuant to mutual aid agreement other intergovernmental agreement or the village is otherwise justly compensated by a unit of government 4 funeral processions 5 block parties 6 parades that receive financial contributions from the village special services means the exclusive allocation of village resources including but not limited to village personnel equipment rightsofway or property for use in conjunction with a special event as requested by the host or sponsor of the event or requested by or on behalf of any person attending the event special services shall include but not be limited to any of the following 1 street closures  2 requiring police officers or other public safety personnel to stop or reroute traffic during the special event  3 special police protection during the special event  4 stationary emergency vehicles at or in the immediate vicinity of the special event providing firefighters paramedics or firefighting equipment or ambulances at the event  5 requiring additional garbage removal or street sweeping services  6 special signage such as temporary no parking signs  7 the use of any village building equipment or other property for any purpose other than the normal daily operations of the village  8 and otherwise providing exclusive services sponsor means the organization or entity on whose behalf the authorized representative has applied for a permit under this article and to whom the permit is issued village equipment includes any vehicle of any type that is owned leased or used by the village and any equipment owned leased or used by the village in providing firefighting police emergency medical services or public works services village personnel shall mean fulltime and parttime employees or volunteers of the village employees of other municipalities which provide services to or for the village pursuant to a mutual aid or other intergovernmental cooperation agreement and independent contractors who provide services to or for the village village property shall mean any and all real or personal property owned leased or used by the village and all public streets sidewalks or rightsofway within the village  permit requirements no person or entity shall conduct a special event without first having to obtain a special event permit from the village in conformance with the terms of this article  permit application and processing a permit application all applications for special event permits shall be delivered to the village administrators office no less than sixty 60 days prior to the proposed event b form and content of application the application shall be in writing and shall be accompanied by the required application fee the certificate of insurance and the indemnification and hold harmless agreement required by this article the application shall provide the following information 1 the name address daytime telephone number cellular telephone and if applicable email address of the sponsor submitting the application and the sponsors authorized representative who will manage or direct the special event if applicable  2 a general description of the special event including the street addresslocation the dates and the beginning time and ending time and if it is parade the route to be followed  3 the approximate number of persons expected to participate in the event and the basis on which the estimate is made  4 whether access to the event requires payment by participants or if the event is open to the public without required payment  5 a description of any proposed food drink or alcoholic beverage preparation or sales  6 a description of the services village personnel village equipment and village property which the applicant requests the village to provide including the applicants estimate of the number and type needed and the basis on which the estimate is made  7 a detailed description of all public rightsofway and private streets for which the applicant requests the village to restrict or alter normal parking vehicular traffic or pedestrian traffic patterns the nature of such restrictions or alterations and the basis of the need for the same  and 8 a statement signed by the applicant either agreeing to pay all fees and meet all other requirements of this article or representing to the village that the applicant is duly authorized to make such agreement on behalf of the entity holding or sponsoring the special event  and 9 any additional information the village deems reasonably necessary in order to properly plan for the villages provision of special services for the event in no event or circumstances shall the village request any information regarding the content of speech or other communications which may occur at the special event c application review and procedures 1 all applications for a special event permit shall be processed on a first come first served basis 2 the village administrator shall be responsible for promptly processing all applications including conferring with department heads and applicants as necessary to implement the provisions of this article the village administrator shall approve approve with conditions and modifications or deny the special event permit application 3 the village administrator may refer the application to the village board for consideration if the village administrator determines such consideration is warranted by the nature and extent of the villages resources required to accommodate the event 4 the village administrator shall promptly distribute the copies of the application for review by any department head from which special services are requested or required each department head shall review the application and evaluate the special services requested and shall report to the village administrator an estimate cost for the special services pursuant to section 9910 required along with a recommendation that the requested special services be approved approved with conditions or modifications or denied any such recommendations shall comply with the standards or procedures setforth in section 9904 5 prior to denying a special event permit application or granting a special event permit subject to conditions or modifications the village administrator or his designee shall confer with the applicant andor responsible party to attempt to agree on terms under which the permit can be issued which may include but shall not be limited to considering other dates or locations for the event having the events sponsors or organizers obtain certain services from private vendors or having the village provide other or additional special services where required by the unique nature of the event d standards for review and issuance of permits 1 no special event permit application shall be denied for any grounds other than those setforth in this section whenever a special event permit is recommended for denial or is denied the reasons for the recommendation of denial shall be set forth in writing 2 no special event permit application shall be approved with conditions or modifications unless such conditions and modifications are consistent with the provisions of this section and are set forth in writing in the permit e certificate of insurance no village personnel equipment property or services shall be provided for special events unless the applicant provides the village with a certificate of insurance for the special event in such amounts as the village may prescribe and naming the corporate authorities officers officials boards commissions employees agents and representatives as additional insured f indemnification and hold harmless the permit application shall be accompanied by the indemnification agreement provided by the village g reservation of rights to the extent permitted by law the village of roselle reserves the following rights 1 to deny a permit for any of the following a the application contains incomplete or false information or is not fully completed or executed b the applicant has not tendered the required application fee with the application or not tendered the user fee indemnification agreement or insurance certificate required by this article  c the applicant is not legally authorized and competent to bind the responsible party  and d the responsible party is not legally competent to contract or to sue or be sued  and e the applicant does not otherwise comply with the terms of this article f the special event is for an activity that is illegal under federal state or village law  2 to order the cessation of the special event if the village administrator chief of police fire chief or designees determine that any of the terms and conditions of the permit have been violated  3 to order cessation of the special event if the village administrator chief of police fire chief or designees determine the operation of the special event is creating a public nuisance or hazardous condition provided that the event shall be allowed to resume upon abatement of the nuisance or hazardous condition  4 to deny a permit if the applicant responsible party or person on whose behalf of the application is submitted a has an outstanding balance due from a prior special event  b has on prior occasions damaged village property and has not paid in full for such damage  c has other outstanding debts to the village  d has on prior occasions made material misrepresentations regarding the nature and extent of special services required for a special event in the village  e has violated the terms of a prior special event permit  5 to deny a permit if a the event will substantially or unnecessarily interfere with traffic in the village will interfere with access to the fire station or fire hydrants or will interfere with businesses or residences in the immediate vicinity of the event  b there are not available at the time of the proposed event sufficient village resources to mitigate the disruptions  6 to deny the permit if a the special services required for the event will substantially or unnecessarily interfere with police fire public works or other services to the village as a whole  and b there are not available at the time of the proposed event sufficient village resources to mitigate the disruption  and c the person or entity applying for the special events permit is not capable of providing the additional resources sources  7 to deny a permit if a the proposed date and time of the special event conflicts with a previously scheduled event and b there are not sufficient village resources available at the time of the proposed special event to provide services for both events without substantially or unnecessarily interfering with police fire public works or other services to the village as a whole  8 to impose requirements conditions or restrictions for the conduct of the special event other than or in additional to those provided in this article if the village acting village administrator or the village board determines that such other or additional requirements conditions or restrictions which shall be stated in writing in the permit are necessary to protect the public health safety or welfare  9 to refer an application to the village board for consideration if the request is also subject to a provision of the village requires the boards approval or if the village administrator determines such consideration is warranted by the nature and extent of the applicants request for the villages resources required to accommodate the event  10 to waive some or all fees associated with this article if in the opinion of the village board that it is in the best interest of the village  inspections the village shall make reasonable inspections to determine if the following conditions are met 1 adequate aisles for pedestrians and fire separation between structures attractions and sales areas  2 sufficient exits marked and properly lighted  3 proper safeguarding of the use of any open flames  4 all combustible decorative materials including curtains streamers and cloth are rendered fireproof  5 satisfactory sanitary facilities on or near the premises on which the event is to occur are sufficient for the public  6 adequate wiring on all temporary electrical fixtures  7 arrangements for the proper servicing of all areas where debris may be expected to accumulate  8 adequate traffic circulation and parking provisions for patrons  9 noise levels are controlled so as not to become a nuisance to adjacent uses  10 adequate security and crowd control  11 adequate traffic control at all entrances to public streets  12 lighting does not intrude upon adjacent residential properties if any each permit issued hereunder shall contain the provision that police fire and other authorized officials of the village shall have the right to free access to the grounds and all buildings structures booths shows and concessions and any other attractions on such grounds to inspect and enforce compliance with the provisions of this article if access to police fire or other authorized official of the village is denied access for any reason the permit shall be immediately revoked  authority to village administrator in determining whether to approve a special event permit the village administrator may consider factors reasonably deemed relevant for the proposed event and necessary to secure the
